data.title: A Guide to the Most Scenic Films Shot in Greece
data.meta_description: From Michael Cacoyannis’s famed Zorba the Greek to the beachy musical that is Mamma Mia!, these are our favorite Greece-set films.
data.text:
Before Midnight, 2013

Richard Linklater

The third and final film in Richard Linklater’s trilogy, Before Midnight finds Julie Delpy and Ethan Hawke reminiscing about their love and life together on holiday in Greece. They're on the Peloponnese peninsula, where they spend their evening together, watching the sun set the sky ablaze in orange before it dips into the dusky sea.

To watch, click here.

Boy on a Dolphin, 1957

Jean Negulesco

This was the first Hollywood film shot in Greece, and Italian actress Sophia Loren’s English-language debut as a dazzling sponge diver. Loren discovers a sunken ship off the coast of the Aegean Sea filled with priceless treasures, including an ancient gold statue of a boy on a dolphin. Archaeologist Alan Ladd and antiques dealer Clifton Webb vie for both her attention and the artifact. All this is set against the backdrop of the mystical island of Hydra.

To watch, click here.

Eleni 1985

Peter Yates

John Malkovich is a New York Times journalist sent to a post in Greece, where he takes the opportunity to investigate and exact revenge on the Communist guerrillas who killed his mother during the civil war 30 years prior. The plot is heavy but the remote village where the story unfolds is filled with centuries-old olive trees and traditional stone cottages.

To watch, click here.

Greek author Theo Angelopoulos paints a picture of the ancient islands away from the tourist beaches, instead focusing on ailing poet Alexander (Bruno Ganz) musing on his life as he travels Greece in the company of an Albanian boy he’s taken under his wing.

To watch, click here.

Mamma Mia, 2008

Phyllida Lloyd

Love it or hate it, this movie—based on the 1999 musical set to the songs of Swedish pop group ABBA—delivers some of the most alluring shots of Greece in film. Shot mostly on the island of Skopelos, the film features an all-star cast consisting of Meryl Streep, Colin Firth, Pierce Brosnan, Christine Baranski, Stellan Skarsgård, Amanda Seyfried, and Dominic Cooper. As they synchronize swim in the “can’t believe it’s that blue” sea to the songs of ABBA, one can almost hear the call of the Sirens. For more, there’s Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again!, which premiered in 2018 and is a series of flashbacks of a young Donna (Meryl Streep) and her life in England before moving to Greece.

To watch, click here.

Mediterraneo, 1991

Gabriele Salvatores

After their ship is sunk by the Allies during WWII, a group of misfit Italian soldiers wash up on what they thought to be a deserted island—only to discover there are people. Soon, they forget they are in the middle of a war. They pass the hours playing soccer with the locals, bobbing about the sea in tiny fishing boats, and learning how to dance like the Greeks.

To watch, click here.

My Life in Ruins, 2009

Donald Petrie

Nia Vardalos never actually gets to Greece in My Big Fat Greek Wedding but the film’s sequel finds her traversing Greece as a tour guide. She hits up all the obvious tourist destinations including the Parthenon and the Acropolis—the film marked the first time that an American film studio was allowed to shoot on location at the historic site.

Never on Sunday, 1960

Jules Dassin

In this romantic comedy, Ilya is a free-spirited Greek prostitute living in the port of Piraeus. She’s out on the town—downing ooza and dancing the Sirtaki with a different gentleman friend—every day except for, as the title suggests, Sunday. Its star, Melina Mercouri, won best actress for playing Ilya at the 1960 Cannes Film Festival.

To watch, click here.

Phaedra, 1962

Jules Dassin

Phaedra (Melina Mercouri), the wife of a shipping tycoon, wants for nothing—except for her husband’s son (Anthony Perkins) from his first marriage, who she instantly falls in love with. The two begin an affair, which has devastating results. It’s a bit of a Greek tragedy but there are magnificent moments of island life (Hydra) along the way.

To watch, click here.

Shirley Valentine, 1986

Jules Dassin

In this dry British comedy, bored English housewife Shirley Valentine impulsively joins her friend on a trip to Greece where she embarks on a holiday romance with a local taverna owner. She realizes her dreams of sipping wine by the sea and sunsets and skinny dips with her new lover named Costas—it’s a quintessential holiday film.

Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants, 2005

Ken Kwapis

Spending their first summer apart, four teenage American best friends played by Blake Lively, Alexis Bledel, Amber Tamblyn, and America Ferrera promise to keep in touch by sharing a pair of blue jeans that inexplicably fits them all like a glove. Bledel visits her Greek grandparents in Santorini, Lively departs for soccer camp in Mexico, Tamblyn stays home in Maryland, and Ferrera visits her estranged father in South Carolina. Each find their own version of summertime bliss, but none more so than Lena (Alexis Bledel) who meets the tall, dark, and handsome fisherman Kostas Dounas amongst the whitewashed cubiform homes, rugged hillside, and crystal blue waters of the Aegean Sea.

To watch, click here.

Suntan, 2016

Argyris Papadimitropoulos

On an unnamed Greek island, a local doctor spends a dreary winter. But come summer, the pleasure-seeking vacationers arrive. The doctor falls for a tourist who lures him into a hard-partying binge with late-night dance parties at the beach followed by lazy days spent recovering beneath the sun. She's just having fun but he's on the verge of complete obsession.

To watch, click here.

The Greek Tycoon, 1978

J. Lee Thompson

A film à clef starring Anthony Quinn as a Greek shipping heir—based on Aristotle Onassis—and his love affair with Jacqueline Bisset, based on First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy. Though the film bombed at the box office, the allure of the lavish jet-set characters and the scenes of labyrinthine streets leading to whitewashed villas are hard to deny.

To watch, click here.

The Guns of Navarone, 1961

J. Lee Thompson

Inspired by the Battle of Leros during the Dodecanese Campaign of World War II, The Guns of Navarone stars Gregory Peck, Anthony Quinn, and David Niven as Allied soldiers sent to destroy German weapons on the Greek island of Navarone. Yes, it’s technically a war film, but there are some beautiful vistas of Classical ruins and rocky beaches. Fun fact: In one scene, members of the Greek royal family appear in the background as extras.

To watch, click here.

The Trip to Greece, 2020

Michael Winterbottom

The final installment of Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon's riotous sojourns is The Trip to Greece. The pair of comedians are up to their old antics as they traveling from Troy to Ithaca in the mythical footsteps of Odysseus. There’s a particularly hilarious scene where the two vie for the best Arnold Schwarzenegger impression and almost forget how beautiful their seaside luncheon is.

The Two Faces of January, 2014

Hossein Amini

A twisty tale of extortion and murder, this is the story of a holiday gone wrong. But before all that, the vacationers, played by Viggo Mortensen and Kirsten Dunst, are enjoying Athens, touring the Acropolis and taking meals alfresco. Plus, given that the film is set in 1962, there's some great fashion for Dunst's character.

To watch, click here.

Zorba the Greek, 1964

Michael Cacoyannis

Anthony Quinn will forever be associated with his role as Zorba the Greek, immortalized in the iconic Sirtaki dancing scene, filmed on the beach in Crete. The epic film showcases rural Greek life including mining and logging communities in Crete, to the coastal town of Chania. Though black-and-white, it’s easy to imagine the deep blue of the sea.

To watch, click here.

A Touch of Spice, 2003

Tassos Boulmetis

A young boy stays connected to his childhood city of Istanbul through cooking his grandfather’s recipes after his family is deported to Athens, Greece—a result of the anti-Greek activities undertaken by the Turkish government in the late 1950s. Scenes of a bustling Istanbul and Athens create the backdrop for this foodie film.

To watch, click here.
